question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The Dialogue Lab completely transformed how I understand human communication. First, I learned to truly listen - not just to words, but to the subtle layers of meaning, emotion, and intention that flow beneath them. Second, I discovered how a group of strangers sitting in a circle can create an entirely new "collective consciousness" through dialogue, where our shared understanding becomes deeper than any one person's individual thoughts. Finally, and most importantly, I learned that what seems like "just talking" is actually an incredibly complex dance of human connection, where every word, pause, and response shapes not only our conversation but who we become as people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: HOLY. Look. You learn skills that can't be taught anywhere else at Duke. You get to truly see people, and be seen as a person. It's an entirely different WAY of learning, and it's so challenging but so fun and (imo) much much less stressful than how we've been doing it for all of our lives. You're pretty much guaranteed a good grade as long as you buy in. With that being said, while this class doesn't demand stress, it does demand investment. You have to be present and attentive and willing to be a bit uncomfortable. Try it out!! You will 100% see if you love it or hate it within the first 2 weeks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I learned to see conversations as a way to build meaning collaboratively, not just exchange ideas. I'm an international student, and taking this course with Prof. Landes has given me the language and toolbox to approach everyday conversations as fun toys rather than something we just "do". Notably, I don't think the course gave me "new tools" or "tips and tricks" for having conversation, but rather gave me (1) a space and a community to experiment with and get honest voices and advice about my communication, and (2) a language to explicate what might feel "right" or "wrong" within a conversation and what each action might contribute to a conversation.- I started recognizing that every interaction is shaped by interpretive lenses, helping me better analyze the dynamics at play. This idea was also formed in his past class (WRIT 101) and it plays hand-in-hand perfectly with this class. Two extremely impactful ideas that I continuously repeat to my friends that I've learned throughout my time learning with him were that (1) there is no such thing as an "objective" or "true" lens, and (2) particularities--not generalities--foster the relatability within a narrative/story. Definitely use the language we built in this class over interpretive lenses in my everyday life.- I realized the value of embracing ambiguity and using it to explore deeper, more nuanced perspectives rather than seeking immediate clarity. A lot of the people that come in are CS/Engineering majors that are very used to the dry-cut communication of numbers and fact (self-included). This course (and Prof. Landes' approach) give us a culture shock that "useless" conversations are where true humanity shows up and how people connect.

3. How to engage in healthy, efficient dialogue.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The circular seating arrangement and lab-style structure of this course was absolutely brilliant - it broke down traditional classroom hierarchies and created this incredible space where we could truly experiment with communication. Landes was more like a skilled facilitator than a traditional instructor, guiding our discussions with light touches while letting us discover profound insights on our own. The weekly "lab reports" were genius because they forced me to process and analyze what happened in our discussions, helping me see patterns and dynamics I would have totally missed otherwise. I especially loved how responsive the course was to our group's specific needs - when we'd hit communication roadblocks or discover interesting tangents, the professor would adapt assignments and readings to help us explore those areas deeper, making everything feel incredibly relevant and personally meaningful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I've taken WRIT 101 and WRIT267S with Prof. Landes back-to-back. I've had a lot of conversations him inside and outside of the class, and he has definitely earned my full respect over the year or so that I've met him. It's the type of respect that comes when you know someone is *extremely* convinced and in love with what they do and put in the time to understand it and study it well. Once you speak to him and understand the context of his experience in the past, who he taught, his hobbies, you gain more and more of an appreciation to his relationship with the subject. You start to feel like it is his literal baby or "magnum opus". Regardless, Prof. Landes leads the class with the mentality of trying to simply enhance your growth, not particularly direct it. He gives advice and treats people as individuals with separate interests and personalities, which makes the class have a very amplified personality. Some of the advice, experiences, and lessons he has shared with me have even contributed to my personal life in an extremely concrete way. Conversations with him are dense with lessons that are applicable to the class and beyond.As for specific components of the course that stood out to me, the focus away from the usual educational banking model and letting the class direct the conversations of the day is definitely the star of the show for me. Prof. Landes is insanely good at letting conversations happen and only talking when he has to or when it adds to the conversation. I felt a real connection with the class for sure. There is a reason why I felt so strongly about taking this class after WRIT 101--similar feelings were felt in that course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- The impact of improved technology (AI), pharmaceuticals, and frameworks like value-based care have on the U.S. healthcare system.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You must take this course if you are at all interested in the financial, political, or social climate surrounding the U.S. healthcare system. Professor Sangvai has a lot of anecdotes and the class discussion is always fun. We always had engaging slides and discussions in class and the professor was very respectful of our time starting the class on time and often letting us leave a couple minutes early. This course has a large emphasis on class discussion, so you will really enjoy this class if you are the type to ask questions and talk in class, but might not enjoy it if you are the type to sit in the back of the classroom and play games during class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about assessment in higher education, including how research is conducted, key considerations to make when enacting assessment, what assessment does for the institutions, controversies in the higher education space, as well as key issues to consider when planning an assessment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe that I learned lots of skills that were very helpful to not only expand my knowledge in this courses, but in general. I learned about the different ways the schools assess their quality of education, the tools to assessing education, and ways in which to improve assessment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me a lot about how to create a research proposal. Prior to the course, I knew little to nothing about audience, methodology, conceptual frameworks, limitations of studies, etc. I also learned so much about higher education in general and how universities operate which I found so interesting as a student in college.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) How to write a research paper/program evaluation from start to finish
2) How to critically examine the ways in which programs operate
3) Better understand how the various components of the university and higher education landscape interact with each other, especially accreditation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the broad definition of assessment and how it is used in higher education. I also learned a lot more about the landscape of higher education and the different stakeholders involved. Finally, this class helped me develop research method and critical thinking skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the process and purpose of assessment of higher education, direct and indirect measurements, and ethical guidelines for research involving subjects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned the various methods of assessment, including surveys, focus groups and interviews, portfolios, employer evaluation, etc. 
2. I learned how to think through research ethics and potential threats to research conduct that can occur in human subjects research
3. I learned how to iteratively write a research proposal and how to integrate different streams of thought into a cohesive proposal

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Facilitated learning through engaging discussions that highlighted key takeaways from the readings assigned. The instructor also led a semester-long assessment proposal, gave effective and comprehensive feedback for each weekly assignment, and offered office hours to help supplement our learning when we needed it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Hill was an extremely helpful instructor. Not only was she incredibly flexible with her time, but she gave incredibly detail feedback on all of our writing assignments. Every week, we had at least one big writing assignment due and just a few days after, she would return it with ways to make it better. This improved my learning and consistent engagement with the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was very engaging and I found the presentations to be really interesting and also informative. Stand-ups were also really great because it gave me the opportunity to do a low stakes presentation and learn about a specific concept in a new way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The rubrics are fantastic. For every assignment, Dr. Hill provides a rubric that outlines exactly what she expects. Between the rubrics and the line-by-line feedback that she provides for all of our papers, I couldn't ask for a more beneficial learning experience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was great! She cared a lot about each of her students, which was evident by her frequent check-ins. She went above and beyond with feedback as well, which also motivated me to be extra thoughtful in the work that I submitted as well. I liked how the instructor spaced out the writing prompts so that we would work on the writing project throughout the semester. I also like how the instructor spaced her office hours to be before assignments were due. Finally, I liked how we had 2 drafts of the methodology section. I also really liked the stand ups! Finally, I enjoyed the opportunity to engage in an oral interview for the second article critique.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: One small detail I appreciated is how Dr. Hill would randomly say one of our names while giving hypothetical examples i.e. "Suppose that (name) was working on x and received feedback from....".  It was a real subtlety but it was helpful in staying engaged.  The learning was also facilitated by the conversational aspect of the course, the lecture slides (and how they were styled), as well as the incredibly detailed feedback on all of our writing assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Hill was one of the most organized instructors I have had at Duke (she also provides an incredible amount of timely feedback). I really appreciated the clarity in which she presented information and assignments. The iterative nature of the course requires consistent work throughout the semester. But, it's a good learning process and retrospectively I believe the process of revision has allowed me to produce better writing. I also liked the oral interview option for the second article critique. It pushed me to communicate my ideas and arguments in a different manner.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The semester-long proposal based on assessment of a key issue we were interested in was the most stimulating because it allowed us to apply the concepts we have learned in the course regarding assessment to a research proposal where we can develop our research writing skills.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that it expanded my knowledge in many ways, but I did feel like sometimes the papers that we read were very redundant. I liked when we read more specific case studies so we had more concrete information and examples to help guide us.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will challenge your beliefs about what research actually looks like, and that does not just apply to research in higher education.  Dr. Jennifer Hill is an excellent instructor who will help guide you every step of the way as you expand your knowledge of proper research techniques, but you will still struggle, and that's completely okay.  You don't need to be familiar with statistical models or research ethics prior to starting this course.  Just go into it with an open mind, and you'll be fine.  Be prepared for a fair amount of writing, though.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a class that you won't be able to fall behind in but I also feel that this class has pushed me to improve my writing skills and my ability to consider feedback and revise.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: equity in stem, culture of engineering, what it means to be a woman in stem right now

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about equity in STEM education, and the effects that stem can be affected by equityequity  outcomes and being affected by things which can sometimes be outside of some people's outcomes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think for me it helped prepared me for my career as a teacher. If I end becoming a STEM teacher I learned way how to make sure my students can get access to STEM resources and education and prepare them for spaces that might not be accessible to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. the importance of STEM education in children
2. the ways that underrepresented communities are actively hurt by current educational systems
3. what i can do to promote stem equity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We developed the ability to think about inequities that exist in the ways STEM is taught to students. We also learned about the flaws in the ways the pathways to STEM are conceptualized, with the leaky pipeline being a misconception that perpetuates the idea that people passively fall out of the pathway to STEM rather than it being lack of access, resources, or harsh standards without proper help being given pushing people out. We also learned about the importance of one's STEM ecosystem, these being a collection of people who help an individual through their STEM journey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of inclusivity in STEM and how it can make younger people feel more confident in themselves and their abilities when they have a good foundation of STEM activities in their youth.  I also learned about how minorities are dealing with underrepresentation in STEM as they go on to university and how it effects their careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about qualitative modes of research, culture capitol, STEM ecosystems

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned a lot about other student's experiences and how important it is to consider external factors that may impact their success and education. This knowledge can also be applied to my workplace.
- I learned how to wield language in a way that impacts my community positively.
- I have gained skills to combat social norms and am prepared to channel positive change in my communities through DukeEngage.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Generally, I liked the readings provided.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! But also, don't be afraid to ask for help, and then just do your best and execute/produce assignments that you are proud of.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to read and engage in class. All the professors are very nice and understanding so don't be afraid to let them know about anything that is bothering you. I also really loved the service learning proponent and was honestly my favorite part of the class so if interacting with kids isn't something you like, don't take this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will sneak up on you with the work if you're not careful. Granted, aside from the weekly reflections and service learning requirement, there are only a few assignments. However, they are worth a lot of your grade, and the rubrics were pretty ambiguous. There are also lots of mini-projects you do during class that are quite impromptu and you don't get a lot of time to work on them, so be aware of that. Lastly, if you don't go to a service learning session one time, you may be a little lost during the thirty minutes during each class where you are preparing for it. Still, this is a very good course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this class if you're an underclassman - a lot of what's covered would have been so helpful for me to know (e.g. how to apply to grad school, develop an elevator pitch, cover letter, what different research can look like, finding great mentorship, all the instructors in the class would be fantastic mentors for your college experience)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned more about duke's history and the backstory of the men's basketball programs. I also was able to read and learn more about significant Black figures in athletics. As well as do reflections over our readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How NCAA works and its controversies, analyzing through historical documents, how racial stereotypes come from?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never taken a class that was sports related so I learned a lot, but I feel that most of my learning was based on conversations with one another and discussions with the basketball players and athletes in my class as opposed to actual class content. I don't necessarily think this is an issue though, as I learned a lot and having peaceful discourse is super important. I liked how the class was very discussion based because as long as you were engaged in the content, you could easily participate. I had a lot of fun in this class too!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned knowledge of psuedo science and fitting science for your own needs. I learned a lot of history of Duke and feel much more informed on the places I go at duke. I think this course offers insight into understanding sports much better for a person who knows nothing about it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my ability to express my beliefs

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course taught me how to think societally and contextually. The course challenged my previous biases and preconceived notions about race, education, and athletics. The course did a phenomenal job of making me consider core elements of Duke within a racial context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Having to really say everything im thinking with no shortcuts, Debating about topics I care about, Learned a lot about black culture and the stereotypes around it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the NCAA, racial biases in basketball, and about early black athletes at Duke like CB Claiborne

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course has allowed me to gain a lot of valuable knowledge on the history of race and sport on the local, national, and international levels. Through this course I have been able to shift my ways of thinking about student athletes and their journeys and how the topic relates to much larger issues concerning our society such as education, race, immigration, class, and gender. The dynamic nature of this class has opened my my eyes to the complexities of the intercollegiate basketball system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more about Durham's history, the history of the Duke men's basketball program, and how the NCAA works. I got a much more critical lens about things I've been seeing my entire life. I also learned more about how to take a step back and analyze myself in larger systems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed great background knowledge and insights into the history of Duke Basketball. We learned about C.B Claiborne who was the first African American basketball player to attend Duke. We learned about his hardships and journey while attending this institution. Also, we talked about the secret game which was a pick up game between Duke and NCCU that wasnt allowed at that time because of racial tension.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. the history of Duke and Duke basketball 
2. an understanding of contemporary issues and discussions in collegiate athletics 
3. the ability to have respectful discussions with people with different beliefs

2. Playing devil's advocate to make sure I feel strongly in my opinion
3. Getting better at debating between classmates with topics we feel different about

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Wallace is a truly phenomenal instructor. He is a great lecturer. He stands out as a professor because he connects with students. He does a phenomenal job of challenging students in a way that makes them consider their perspectives. He also is incredibly captivating and incredibly knowledgeable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked our readings and I thought that the length of the discussion papers really made me think my way through assignments and give whatever topic we were learning my full attention. I also thought that hearing and encouraging the basketball players to share their perspectives was key in not only giving more information, but demonstrating the real world impact of what we were learning in class. Last, I really enjoyed the tour we took with Jeanette Llorens. She did an amazing job and I think it brought a lot of extra context to the course. I also really enjoyed the auto-biography project in the class, although, going foward, I think there should be a little bit more guidance about how much information we should put in it, considering that some people's had a lot more information than others. Regardless, I thought that having us all talk about our backgrounds helped us relate to and understand each other better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I really appreciated how every person had to share a story each class, and had the freedom to share almost whatever they wanted, regardless of whether it was a story they had told before. It kept me thinking about storytelling but took away some of the pressure of having a new, life-changing tale each week. I also genuinely found the readings for this course engaging and helpful; I wish we had discussed them more during class times. 
I thought the start of the course was particularly engaging, when we were given storytelling prompts and told to generate ideas on the spot. I wish we had done more exercises like that related to idea generation throughout the course, as I really enjoyed it,

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of desegregation, why policy and social movements failed, and why resegregation is occurring.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Learned how to rethink strategies when it comes to approaching service learning. 
Learned the history of racial segregation in the state of education. 
Learned how to understand the overlapping factors in the battle of desegregation

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Using a historical lens, reading in depth, and communicating within a group of people with a diverse assortment of lived experiences

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the historical timeline of segregation in education in America and learned to think about issues like Brown v Board critically. I also learned to look introspectively on my own experience within the public education system. I also learned to view resources carefully and consider bias/motives/perspectives that may be hidden.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We studied the history of segregation, ways schools avoided desegregation orders, and ways school districts are re-segregregating today

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about magnet schools, school choice, and charter schools, and the variety of perspectives that individuals had with each. I realized that while you can increase the amount of resources available in a school, such as standardized test preparation, it doesn't mean that all students will be able to access those resources. Finally, I learned about the difference between school desegregation, integration, and segregation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- the history of segregation and its effects today 
- systems and policies that have contributed to de/re/segregation 
- understanding of different decisions and rulings across different school districts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

-How to give descriptive feedbacks to others and how to revise my draft using those feedbacks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed many skills and methods of thinking relating to academic writing through this course. We learned about the various nuances of academic writing as a genre in different fields and through a holistic view. The main thing we learned is that academic writing is very much a genre of convention, where scholars tend to follow trends and patterns set by the writers who came before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is a very helpful course for me to develop research writing skills. Many other courses won't provide such a constructive and helpful process of writing a research paper. The ways that the reading materials are organized and the mini-assignments we completed really helped me narrow down very specific techniques used in academic writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to give helpful peer feedback, I learned best practices for orchestrating sources, and I learned tactics for reading and digesting lots of academic articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Giltrow et al. exercises are super helpful because they include many examples from academic articles and non-scholarly sources. The mini-assignments are also pretty helpful; they allow us to break down a research paper into small pieces and then put them all together.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: All around a great class with a clear and helpful pedagogy; it is very evident that Dr. Asmuth isn't just someone here to research and teach on the side but is very intentional about making sure kids learn, and that their drive for doing so is backed by a passion for research.  Some specific components of the course that rocked: I really appreciate that at the beginning of the class, they went over examples of past homework responses and made it very clear what they were and weren’t looking for.  I also like that when they could tell folks were losing attention, they would discreetly call on us and ask a question to bring us back into focus.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is discussion-heavy and has a decent amount of day-to-day work, but it is an interesting class to take if you are interested in writing a thesis or are interested in learning about academic writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Taken two courses with Dr. Asmuth. Super nice professor, very passionate about teaching, and probably one of the best at Duke. There are a lot of assignments, but you will learn a lot later in the semester once you complete all of them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are working on a thesis as I am, this class is a must! For starters, it held me accountable to finish deliverables for my thesis that had looser deadlines, which was very helpful.  Beyond that, I had fellow classmates stress a lot at the beginning of the thesis class because we were told to write a literature review without many of having learned what a literature review was, but this course had told me exactly what a literature review was and provided me with a myriad of best practices for writing one.  The readings are not too challenging but very rewarding, so do them all.  This class is well worth anyone's time and I expect to use what I learned in this class in job interviews and my future career.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I absolutely loved this course. It was one of the most helpful courses that I took at Duke. However, the class does require a lot of time commitment, averaging around eight hours of work per week. I would definitely recommend taking this course if you are looking to improve your writing skills and learn how to write a good research paper. The amount of feedback you get on all your work will drastically improve your writing skills. Additionally, Dr. Asmuth is very clear with their expectations, meaning that it is possible to do well in the course if you put in the work. The grading criteria is detailed and you will not receive a bad score with no justifications.I would not recommend for you to take this course if you are looking for an easy writing credit.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was incredible. I would say the best one I have taken at Duke. The set up of having relevant readings due for class time made for extremely engaging discussion. I loved the places we went for service learning, particularly the museum.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this course due to Leslie's stellar way of teaching. She taught us how to recognize or find community, understand our values, and feel a stronger connection to Durham. All of the projects helped me learn more from my communities and inspired me to progress in new directions like going to business school down the line. I loved not only clarifying my values but also learning what my peers value and who they are. Additionally, the guest speakers and readings we did reminded me that I'm part of an ecosystem outside of Duke that has political and social implications like meeting representatives from the Pauli Murray center or reading up fascinating texts before speaking with community leaders in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned so much from my peers. I gained insights about how to think about the future and how our ideas about success and failure are so often shaped by societal and western perspectives (like living at home after graduation). Also thinking about what makes people interesting: "to be interesting is to be interested." I also gained insights into what independence actually means: it's not about doing things on your own, but about doing things autonomously and for oneself (even though that can often mean doing things for others!)
I really liked Hello Beautiful also!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Preparation for adulthood - what it means to be an adult, expectations (general and female-specific), parenting your inner child, work culture, etc. How to make a Zine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the class we focused on discussing life post-college. There was a strong focus on discussing our fears as we transition into the next phase of our lives and an open environment for us to be vulnerable during every conversation. We discussed how relationships may change post-college, what it actually means to be an adult, and read several books throughout the semester. The most important learning throughout all of this was that everyone here is also anxious and nervous, and that we're not alone.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I strengthened my active listening skills. 
I strengthened my ability to make connections across diverse sources and disciplines. 
I also learned how to reconcile my expectations of adulthood with various depictions of its reality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the role that identity and womanhood play in our interactions with others, I developed insights into planning for life and careers after college, and I developed skills around group work and creating presentations and lesson plans.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion environment is very authentic where we all share our honest opinions and emotions, which make me feel very comfortable in learning that I'm not alone in this journey and that everyone else is going through the same thing. I also feel very comfortable disagreeing with people and listening to different ideas and learning from my friends. My favorite thing is that the class is not traditionally structured with lectures and homework. We have a lot of time for discussion which is much needed especially in this chaotic senior year.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! So many! Informal discussions, course themes with attached projects, opportunities to choose what we learn about (like in Book Club)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class environment was very open, accepting, and welcoming. The professor encouraged us to share our thoughts even if they weren't well developed and didn't make the discussion participation necessary. By doing so, everyone spoke when they truly wanted to, which made the environment much more relaxed and opening. The class also did not have a big work load. It was mainly just readings and a few projects that were very introspective. The fact that the class was so low stress made it so much more enjoyable. I was genuinely excited every single Monday for class and it makes me super sad I won't have it at all anymore next semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Maxwell prepared a structured course with diverse perspectives, sources, and pedagogical approaches. Maxwell provided clear rubrics and expectations for assignments. In addition, Maxwell offered an objective extension process and advice on balancing the course's workload and outcomes.I believe the course should keep an individual project (project 2) as well as the cohort styled assignments. I would also keep the extension process and feedback. I really appreciated Prof. Maxwell's insights and concern for our class as individuals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed so much emotional intelligence. I gained insights into how to navigate life after college. I gained the skills and insights to understand my college experience and the unique pressures I faced as a woman of color. This helped so much.

Through our group projects, I feel like I have become a better collaborator, recognizing when to lead, when to follow, and how to trust that everything will work out.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned so much from my peers. I gained insights about how to think about the future and how our ideas about success and failure are so often shaped by societal and western perspectives (like living at home after graduation). Also thinking about what makes people interesting: "to be interesting is to be interested." I also gained insights into what independence actually means: it's not about doing things on your own, but about doing things autonomously and for oneself (even though that can often mean doing things for others!)
I really liked Hello Beautiful also!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the class we focused on discussing life post-college. There was a strong focus on discussing our fears as we transition into the next phase of our lives and an open environment for us to be vulnerable during every conversation. We discussed how relationships may change post-college, what it actually means to be an adult, and read several books throughout the semester. The most important learning throughout all of this was that everyone here is also anxious and nervous, and that we're not alone.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I strengthened my active listening skills. 
I strengthened my ability to make connections across diverse sources and disciplines. 
I also learned how to reconcile my expectations of adulthood with various depictions of its reality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the role that identity and womanhood play in our interactions with others, I developed insights into planning for life and careers after college, and I developed skills around group work and creating presentations and lesson plans.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion environment is very authentic where we all share our honest opinions and emotions, which make me feel very comfortable in learning that I'm not alone in this journey and that everyone else is going through the same thing. I also feel very comfortable disagreeing with people and listening to different ideas and learning from my friends. My favorite thing is that the class is not traditionally structured with lectures and homework. We have a lot of time for discussion which is much needed especially in this chaotic senior year.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! So many! Informal discussions, course themes with attached projects, opportunities to choose what we learn about (like in Book Club)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class environment was very open, accepting, and welcoming. The professor encouraged us to share our thoughts even if they weren't well developed and didn't make the discussion participation necessary. By doing so, everyone spoke when they truly wanted to, which made the environment much more relaxed and opening. The class also did not have a big work load. It was mainly just readings and a few projects that were very introspective. The fact that the class was so low stress made it so much more enjoyable. I was genuinely excited every single Monday for class and it makes me super sad I won't have it at all anymore next semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Maxwell prepared a structured course with diverse perspectives, sources, and pedagogical approaches. Maxwell provided clear rubrics and expectations for assignments. In addition, Maxwell offered an objective extension process and advice on balancing the course's workload and outcomes.I believe the course should keep an individual project (project 2) as well as the cohort styled assignments. I would also keep the extension process and feedback. I really appreciated Prof. Maxwell's insights and concern for our class as individuals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about my own identity and how I fit into Duke’s academic environment. As a Black man in STEM, I often felt pressure to conform to a specific image or expectation. This course helped me reflect on how I am not a monolith, I carry a unique perspective shaped by my background, experiences, and passions. I began to realize the power of embracing my full identity in academic spaces rather than trying to fit into a mold.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to better navigate the world of STEM as someone who doesn't always feel as though they fit into the science scene. I also learned about the paths of others, how to advocate for myself, and how to find resources here at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you’re a Spire Fellow, this course is mandatory, but don’t just treat it like a box to check. Lean into the introspection and everything the course offers. Soak it all in, stay honest with yourself, and use what you learn here to your advantage, not just in college, but in life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We developed the ability to think about inequities that exist in the ways STEM is taught to students. We also learned about the flaws in the ways the pathways to STEM are conceptualized, with the leaky pipeline being a misconception that perpetuates the idea that people passively fall out of the pathway to STEM rather than it being lack of access, resources, or harsh standards without proper help being given pushing people out. We also learned about the importance of one's STEM ecosystem, these being a collection of people who help an individual through their STEM journey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of inclusivity in STEM and how it can make younger people feel more confident in themselves and their abilities when they have a good foundation of STEM activities in their youth.  I also learned about how minorities are dealing with underrepresentation in STEM as they go on to university and how it effects their careers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will sneak up on you with the work if you're not careful. Granted, aside from the weekly reflections and service learning requirement, there are only a few assignments. However, they are worth a lot of your grade, and the rubrics were pretty ambiguous. There are also lots of mini-projects you do during class that are quite impromptu and you don't get a lot of time to work on them, so be aware of that. Lastly, if you don't go to a service learning session one time, you may be a little lost during the thirty minutes during each class where you are preparing for it. Still, this is a very good course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: equity in stem, culture of engineering, what it means to be a woman in stem right now

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about equity in STEM education, and the effects that stem can be affected by equityequity  outcomes and being affected by things which can sometimes be outside of some people's outcomes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think for me it helped prepared me for my career as a teacher. If I end becoming a STEM teacher I learned way how to make sure my students can get access to STEM resources and education and prepare them for spaces that might not be accessible to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. the importance of STEM education in children
2. the ways that underrepresented communities are actively hurt by current educational systems
3. what i can do to promote stem equity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We developed the ability to think about inequities that exist in the ways STEM is taught to students. We also learned about the flaws in the ways the pathways to STEM are conceptualized, with the leaky pipeline being a misconception that perpetuates the idea that people passively fall out of the pathway to STEM rather than it being lack of access, resources, or harsh standards without proper help being given pushing people out. We also learned about the importance of one's STEM ecosystem, these being a collection of people who help an individual through their STEM journey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of inclusivity in STEM and how it can make younger people feel more confident in themselves and their abilities when they have a good foundation of STEM activities in their youth.  I also learned about how minorities are dealing with underrepresentation in STEM as they go on to university and how it effects their careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about qualitative modes of research, culture capitol, STEM ecosystems

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned a lot about other student's experiences and how important it is to consider external factors that may impact their success and education. This knowledge can also be applied to my workplace.
- I learned how to wield language in a way that impacts my community positively.
- I have gained skills to combat social norms and am prepared to channel positive change in my communities through DukeEngage.

response_text: Take it! But also, don't be afraid to ask for help, and then just do your best and execute/produce assignments that you are proud of.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to read and engage in class. All the professors are very nice and understanding so don't be afraid to let them know about anything that is bothering you. I also really loved the service learning proponent and was honestly my favorite part of the class so if interacting with kids isn't something you like, don't take this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will sneak up on you with the work if you're not careful. Granted, aside from the weekly reflections and service learning requirement, there are only a few assignments. However, they are worth a lot of your grade, and the rubrics were pretty ambiguous. There are also lots of mini-projects you do during class that are quite impromptu and you don't get a lot of time to work on them, so be aware of that. Lastly, if you don't go to a service learning session one time, you may be a little lost during the thirty minutes during each class where you are preparing for it. Still, this is a very good course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this class if you're an underclassman - a lot of what's covered would have been so helpful for me to know (e.g. how to apply to grad school, develop an elevator pitch, cover letter, what different research can look like, finding great mentorship, all the instructors in the class would be fantastic mentors for your college experience)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered, in somewhat equal parts, Marx's (and Engel's) original thoughts and writings and their modern counterparts in Marxism and Marxist [ecology, feminism, etc.]. Marx's theories of the world were already useful in understanding our modern world, but we also learned about what was different between now/then, and some places where Marx failed to see the entire picture. To be specific: we learned about Marx's earlier ideas of humanism (alienation/estrangement, species-being, reification/fetishism) and how some Marxists viewed them (namely, Jameson's view on popular culture), about Marx's later ideas of historical materialism and his analyses of history (including Capital and the value it represents, primitive accumulation, class struggle, etc.) and how some Marxists view them (for example, Malm's Marxist Ecology and Fraser's take on Marxist Feminism), and ultimately how these two Marx-es (among some others) could serve as a window to a 'larger Marx' - representing the entirety of Marx and his philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- actually reading Capital!!
- genealogy of Marxist thought since Marx
- Marx's concept of commune/communism

Professor Hardt is, obviously, a great lecturer who is both knowledgeable and passionate about Marx and Marxism, while also being able to make it understandable to an audience that might not've inspected Marx, let alone any social philosophy before.

response_text: A lot was learned in terms of consulting processes and wetting center theory. Seeing as that before taking this class I knew nothing about this, a lot was learned. This could be like research methods, encountering disabilities/learning differences in the studio, language differences, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Developed a better, fuller understanding of the diversity of writers, and how intertwined writing and identity are
2) How to work with a student's writing, and how to guide them towards being a better writer
3) The writing center is an incredibly undervalued academic resource on campus

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course developed my critical thinking, communication and writing skills, particularly in the form of analyzing writing processes in order to strengthen my own and other skills as a writer.  It was difficult, but through endless readings, practice consultations, writing project and my skills in these fields were grown tenfold.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my own writing process, my ability to consult others on their academic writing, and further understanding of the importance of writing communities in universities. I became a more skilled writer, procrastinated less on my work, and turned to collaborative settings as I completed writing assignments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned how to critically analyze writing and writing practices of peers and my own.
- I gained experience as a prospective writing consultant to offer helpful feedback to students for a given assignment.
- I problematized the nature of the writing center, questioning its purpose, goals, and how it may create tension with other parts of the university.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got into a major deep dive of writing studio work. The first big lesson I am taking away is better understanding my own and others writing composition process. I was able to reflect on what does my writing process look like, what can be added to it, and how does showcasing my work to others fit in that process. Additionally, I learned of a lot of peer to peer tutoring skills. We read literature that make suggestions such as sitting next to a tuttee, having moments for casual conversation, checking in on students needs, etc. which was helpful to ground what my consultation practices will look like. I also learned the importance of continuing to push what a writing studio can mean/look like. This played a role in developing my final project to think of a community engaged aspect of the writing studio.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about consulting strategies, writing studies, and my own writing and learning processes. This course shifted the way I think about being a listener and helped me reconcile the different attitudes towards writing which I have observed in my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to navigate the writing center as both a tutor and tutee, while considering how my own backgrounds and others' backgrounds may influence our actions. I worked on strengthening my perception of writing as a process, as opposed to a single act, and on how to communicate that theory with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed self-control, reflectiveness, and analytical thinking skills throughout this course. I have been able to withhold myself from taking on a "fix-it" or editorial mindset to writing consulting, thought more deeply about what I am writing about and how it is representative of who I am as a person, and how to be able to dissect and interpret various forms of writing/writing styles/dialects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr Asmuth as an educator was incredibly effective at building an environment where all students felt comfortable conversing openly and honestly. I truly believe rapport building between students and the educator is such an effective way of facilitating meaningful conversation, and should be prioritized by educators in the future. I also really appreciated the setup of the projects, where we would submit several drafts and also have an opportunity to revise at the end— it really emphasizes all that we were reading about writing as a buildable, fluid, and often reflective process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth did a great job of leading interesting class discussions, allowing me to voice my opinions and hear the thoughts of my peers. I also liked the revision element of the course, having to revisit many of my pieces several times and think about ways to improve them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the variety of readings and writing assignments, as well as the opportunity to consult with my peers and with Writing 101 students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth seemed to always be excited to be in class, and consistently provided, thoughtful, helpful, constructive advise which helped me to become a more confident writer, and a better writing consultant.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love how the class focused on open discussion. Most of our time together was us just conversing about the different works we had read for this week with Dr. Asmuth asking prompting questions and encouraging us to further our ideas. I also loved the freedom Dr. Asmuth gave us to simply troubleshoot consultation practices, work together to work on our writing assignments, walk outside for small groups conversations, and more. I think this really allowed us to grow more independent and collaborative as writers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth facilitated my learning by being flexible and accepting of all the different types of work submitting, still offering constructive feedback that would later help me develop my midterm and final portfolios. The structure of the course with all of the readings, discussion posts, and writing assignments really got me thinking and fostered communication with my peers about our various reactions to writing center philosophies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the general pacing of the course to be fair, though at times the deadlines felt very strict (for example, having the consultant philosophy project due a week after the major deliverable project meant I was not able to put as much time and care into the former as I would've liked). The structure of the class itself, the weekly reflections and the four major projects felt reasonable, and I understood why we were doing what we were doing at any given point. The readings all felt relevant, if not a bit tedious to analyze, and a student's mileage may vary regarding their interest/engagement with the content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: While the weekly reading reflections were a bit of a pain at times, it was really helpful to complete as the specific questions that I needed to respond to ensured that I thoroughly read the week's readings. Additionally, the reflections came into play for the major assignments as I was able to reflect on and reference the reflections- making me feel like the reflections deep dives were worth it. I did like that we would be paired up with different people throughout the course of the semester- it made sure I could get to know my peers better and that I could interact with different perspectives on my work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth was very proactive and often reached out with advice or actively encouraged us to seek help from them, which was reassuring because I did find this course to be challenging. I liked the collaborative discussions we had in class as well as how we built upon and synthesized the readings into our personal philosophies. I also liked that we had built in consultations to gain actual experience, as those helped me build a lot of confidence.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth was a very, very helpful resource and guide throughout the course, and I truly felt like they were so encouraging and wanted me and every other student to succeed. Having all of the potential consultants take this class is smart for ensuring we're all on the same page pedagogically, but it also allowed me to meet and get to know many of my future coworkers. I thought having to revise and submit multiple drafts (a first draft, a second for professor comments, and a third in the midterm and/or final portfolio) was a strong choice that encouraged me to actually set aside time to draft and revise.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth gave amazing constructive feedback that has allowed me to reflect on myself as a writer. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
